column4: i'm having some conceptual difficulty making the distinction between gnome the desktop environment and metacity the WM. is it possible to use "gnome" with another window manager (like, fluxbox, icewm, etc)? how do you do such a thing?

for instance, i've installed fluxbox, and noticed that in gdm i can choose between "Gnome" and "Fluxbox" as a "session". But how does that make any sense? I thought Gnome was a desktop environment, while fluxbox is a WM.
it wouldn't really be gnome then... it would be gnome running another window manager inside it.
what about compiz/beryl then? when you use those, gnome still appears to be "gnome"
its the same thing. its beryl running on top of gnome.
so why is it not possible to use another WM within gnome and still maintain the overall gnome experience (whatever that is, i guess)
or is it possible and i am just ignorant about how to accomplish it
because it's the new WM which change the gnome look.
i guess i am just unclear as to what it is gnome actually does and how much of the WM is responsible for defining my desktop environment
is gnome really a "thing", or just a set of libraries and possibly some daemons to let apps interact (dbus etc)
why are we comparing to windows... windows that was released 6 years ago vs ubuntu released last month on your old hardware isn't a fair comparison.

well, i'm not sure it's as apples-to-oranges as you make it out to be. even kwin performs closer to windows on my "old hardware" that gnome/metacity. and i've been trying these things on and off for years with the same results
i'm very surprised you find kwin performs better than GTK.

I don't think KDE overall performs better than Gnome, but kwin is absolutely a more responsive UI experience than metacity in my experience on various machines. i have no idea if this is a factor of using metacity with gnome or what. i never tried to use kwin without kde, for instance (is that even possible?)
thats definitely just your perception then, because i think the majority would agree that gnome runs faster than KDE.
well, i am certainly not going to speak as to what the majority believes or doesn't believe. i just want to know how the heck i can try another WM but retain the gnome feel
beryl/compiz just don't go over gnome's head by running extra panels and stuff.
because bery/compiz aren't full blown desktop environments as Gnome KDE or XFCE are.
so how can i simply replace metacity with fluxbox or whatever WM i want the same way compiz/beryl can
you could start gnome and then run fluxbox.
it may have a --replace function to keep metacity from starting again.
ah ha!
let me give this a shot...
